column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Protein

#Text=N-glycosylation is a critical post-translational modification , in which an oligosaccharide moiety is transferred from the glycosyl carrier dolichol-phosphate ( Dol-P ) and covalently attaches to a polypeptide chain via an asparagine residue .
#Text=Following protein conjugation , the oligosaccharide is further modified , increasing the functional and structural diversity of the proteome .
#Text=Indeed , this modification is crucial for proper protein folding , oligomerization , quality control , sorting , and transport .

#Text=Accordingly , even slight variations in protein glycosylation can markedly affect proteins structure and function and , thus , glycosylation disorders result in a wide range of clinical syndromes affecting practically every organ system .
#Text=Dehydrodolichyl diphosphate synthase ( DHDDS ) together with Nogo-B receptor ( NgBR ) form the human cis -prenyltransferase complex .
#Text=This complex catalyzes the formation of dehydrodolichyl diphosphate ( DHDD ) , a long-chain polyprenyl serving as a precursor for Dol-P .
#Text=DHDD is synthesized by chain elongation of farnesyl diphosphate ( FPP ) via multiple condensations with isopentenyl diphosphate ( IPP ) (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=A ) .

#Text=Importantly , while previous studies revealed that DHDDS is required and sufficient for this catalytic activity , NgBR induces an increase in the expression and activity of the complex but exhibits no catalytic activity .

#Text=In line with the important role of DHDDS in protein glycosylation , mutations in DHDDS were recently shown to cause autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa , a fatal glycosylation disorder , and developmental epileptic encephalopathies .
#Text=Despite the clinical importance of DHDDS , it was not structurally and functionally characterized to date .

#Text=Conserved domains search analysis reveals that the cis -prenyltransferase catalytic domain of DHDDS ( residues 24 – 248 ) is homologous to undecaprenyl pyrophosphate synthase ( UPPS ) , a well characterized bacterial cis -prenyltransferase .
#Text=Consisting of seven α-helices and six β-strands , this domain forms dimers , with a hydrophobic catalytic tunnel surrounded by two α-helices and four β−strands within each monomer .
#Text=In contrast with the N-terminal cis -prenyltransferase homology domain , the C-terminus of human DHDDS does not converge with any known conserved domains .
#Text=Intriguingly , despite the low level of conservation , a C-terminal domain is common to long-chain cis -prenyltransferases and is absent in short- and medium-chain cis -prenyltransferases (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=B ) .
#Text=Nevertheless , its structure and functional role remains elusive .
#Text=Recently , we have devised an efficient procedure for overexpression and purification of human DHDDS in Escherichia coli .
#Text=Similar to the bacterial homolog UPPS , we showed that human DHDDS forms active homodimers .
#Text=However , the molecular details of the interaction interface and the overall architecture of the enzyme remained obscure .

#Text=Here , we determine a structural model for the full-length human DHDDS homodimer using an integrative approach that combines multiple sources of information , including a radioligand-based enzyme kinetics assay , size-exclusion chromatography multi-angle light scattering ( SEC-MALS ) , small-angle X-ray scattering ( SAXS ) , and hydrogen – deuterium exchange mass-spectrometry ( HDX-MS ) .
